line: ABSTRACT GUIDELINES:
label: paragraph

line: A bstracts must include sufficient information for reviewers to judge the nature and significance
label: paragraph

line: of the topic, the adequacy of the investigative strategy, the nature of the results, and the
label: paragraph

line: conclusions. The abstract should summarize the substantive results of the work and not merely
label: paragraph

line: list topics to be discussed.
label: paragraph

line: A n abstract is an outline/brief summary of your paper and your whole project. It should have an
label: paragraph

line: intro, body and conclusion. It is a well-developed paragraph, should be
label: paragraph

line: exact in wording, and must be understandable to a wide audience. Abstracts should be no more
label: paragraph

line: than 250 words, formatted in Microsoft Word, and single-spaced, using size 12 Times New
label: paragraph

line: Roman font.
label: paragraph

line: A bstracts highlight major points of your research and explain why your work is important; what
label: paragraph

line: your purpose was, how you went about your project, what you learned, and what you
label: paragraph

line: concluded.
label: paragraph

line: I f your title includes scientific notation, Greek letters, bold, italics, or other special
label: paragraph

line: characters/symbols, do make sure they appear correctly.
label: paragraph

line: L ist all additional undergraduate co-authors, whether they are or are not presenting, if
label: paragraph

line: applicable.
label: paragraph

line: L ist additional faculty mentors, if applicable.
label: paragraph

line: S IX SAMPLE ABSTRACTS (Previous Participants)
label: paragraph

line: G RADUATE LEVEL
label: paragraph

line: R esearcher: Rita Asgeirsson
label: paragraph

line: P resentation Title: An Analysis of Yukon Delta Salmon Management
label: paragraph

line: Research focus: Fisheries management related to Bering Sea fisheries and Yukon River salmon
label: paragraph

line: populations.
label: paragraph

line: School: Western Washington University
label: paragraph

line: Student Level: Masters
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Type: Oral Presentation
label: paragraph

line: A bstract:
label: paragraph

line: A n Analysis of Yukon Delta Salmon Management
label: paragraph

line: Rita Asgeirsson, Western Washington University
label: paragraph

line: T he broad range of Pacific Alaskan salmon has resulted in the creation of a complex and multi-
label: paragraph

line: organizational system of management that includes the state of Alaska, various federal
label: paragraph

line: departments, a Congressionally-mandated fishery council, and a number of commercial and non-
label: paragraph

line: governmental fish organizations. In the Bering Sea salmon are caught by the commercial
label: paragraph

line: groundfish fleet as by-catch. On the Yukon River salmon are commercially and traditionally
label: paragraph

line: harvested for both economic and cultural sustenance by the Yup’ik residents of the Yukon Delta.
label: paragraph

line: Declining salmon populations has driven scientific research which considers the effects of
label: paragraph

line: Bering Sea salmon by-catch.
label: paragraph

line: M y research findings indicate that Bering Sea fisheries occur where juvenile salmon mature,
label: paragraph

line: directly impacting Yukon River salmon populations. Further, the research reflects that although
label: paragraph

line: Yukon salmon populations have plummeted, a recent effort was made to open the northern
label: paragraph

line: Bering Sea, which includes the Yukon River coastal shelf, to deep-sea commercial fishing.
label: paragraph

line: B y researching the relationship of policy to cultural salmon dependence, it becomes evident that
label: paragraph

line: Alaskan salmon-tribes are excluded from salmon management and decision-making. Legal
label: paragraph

line: research reflects that three basic federal Indian concepts – inherent rights, Indian Country, and
label: paragraph

line: tribal right of occupancy – emerge as potential foundations that may allow Alaskan salmon-
label: paragraph

line: tribes to begin sharing legal responsibility over salmon.
label: paragraph

line: Y ukon River salmon are an international and anadromous species that require multi-
label: paragraph

line: organizational management. My research reflects that current management favors the Bering
label: paragraph

line: Sea commercial fishing industry, despite data indicating Bering Sea fisheries impact Yukon
label: paragraph

line: salmon populations and an overall downward trend in Yukon salmon populations.
label: paragraph

line: Researcher: Alexandrea Bowman
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Title: Using GIS Site Suitability Analysis to Study Adaptability and Evolution of
label: paragraph

line: Life: Locating Springs in Mantle Units of Ophiolites
label: paragraph

line: Research focus: BioGeoChemistry and Computer modelling
label: paragraph

line: School: University of Rhode Island
label: paragraph

line: Student Level: Masters
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Type: Poster Presentation
label: paragraph

line: Abstract:
label: heading

line: Using GIS Site Suitability Analysis to Study Adaptability and Evolution of Life: Locating
label: paragraph

line: Springs in Mantle Units of Ophiolites
label: paragraph

line: Alexandrea Bowman, University of Rhode Island
label: paragraph

line: GIS is a powerful tool that can be used to locate springs sourced in ophiolites. The unique
label: paragraph

line: features associated with these springs include a reducing subsurface environment reacting at low
label: paragraph

line: temperatures producing high pH, Ca-rich formation fluids with high dissolved hydrogen and
label: paragraph

line: methane. Because of their unique chemical characteristics, these areas are often associated with
label: paragraph

line: microbes and are thought to be similar to the features that enabled life to evolve on Earth.
label: paragraph

line: Locating and sampling these springs could offer a deeper look into Earth's deep biosphere and
label: paragraph

line: the history of life on Earth. Springs have tradiitionally been located using expensive and time
label: paragraph

line: consuming field techniques. Field work can be dangerous. The goal of this study was to develop
label: paragraph

line: a model that could locate these unique geological features without first going into the field, thus
label: paragraph

line: saving time, money and reducing the risks associated with remote field localities. A GIS site
label: paragraph

line: suitability analysis works by overlaying existing geo-referenced data into a computer program
label: paragraph

line: and adding the different data sets after assigning a numerical value to the important fields. For
label: paragraph

line: this project, I used surface and ground water maps, geologic maps, a soil map, and a fault map
label: paragraph

line: for four counties in Northern California. The model has demonstrated that it is possible to use
label: paragraph

line: this time of model and apply it to a complex geologic area to produce a usable field map for
label: paragraph

line: future field work.
label: paragraph

line: UNDERGRADUATE LEVEL
label: heading

line: R esearcher: Deneen Cole
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Title: Characterization of Iron Deposition in Recombinant Heteropolymer Ferritins
label: paragraph

line: Research Focus: Chemistry
label: paragraph

line: School: SUNY Potsdam
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Type: Poster Presentation
label: paragraph

line: Abstract:
label: heading

line: Characterization of Iron Deposition in Recombinant Heteropolymer Ferritins
label: paragraph

line: Deneen Cole, Dr. Fadi Bou-Abdallah, SUNY Potsdam (NY, USA), Dr. Paolo Arosio, University
label: paragraph

line: of Brescia (Italy), Dr. Sonia Levi, Vita-Salute San Raffaele University (Italy)
label: paragraph

line: Ferritin is a ubiquitous iron storage and detoxification protein found highly conserved in species
label: paragraph

line: from bacteria to plants to humans. In mammals, ferritin is composed of two functionallyand
label: paragraph

line: genetically distinct subunit types, H (heavy, ~21,000 Da) and L (light, ~19,000 Da) subunits
label: paragraph

line: which co-assemble in various ratios with tissue specific distribution to form a shell-like protein.
label: paragraph

line: The H-subunit is responsible for the fast conversion of Fe(II) to Fe(III) by dioxygen (or H2O2)
label: paragraph

line: whereas the L-subunit is thought to contribute to the nucleation of the iron core. In the present
label: paragraph

line: work, we investigated the iron oxidation and deposition mechanism in two recombinant
label: paragraph

line: heteropolymers ferritin samples of ~20H:4L (termed H/L) and ~22L:2H (termed L/H) ratios.
label: paragraph

line: Data indicates that iron oxidation occurs mainly on the H-subunit with a stoichiometry of
label: paragraph

line: 2Fe(II):1O2, suggesting formation of H2O2. The H/L sample completely regenerates its
label: paragraph

line: ferroxidase activity within a short period of time suggesting rapid movement of Fe(III) from the
label: paragraph

line: ferroxidase center to the cavity to form the mineral core, consistent with the role of L-chain in
label: paragraph

line: facilitating iron turn-over at the ferroxidase center of the H-subunit. In L/H, Fe(II) oxidation and
label: paragraph

line: mineralization appears to occur by two simultaneous pathways at all levels of iron additions: a
label: paragraph

line: ferroxidation pathway with a 2Fe(II)/1O2 ratio and a mineralization pathway with a 4Fe(II)/1O2
label: paragraph

line: resulting in an average net stoichiometry of ~3Fe(II)/1O2.
label: paragraph

line: These results illustrate how recombinant heteropolymer ferritins control iron and oxygen toxicity
label: paragraph

line: while providing a safe reservoir for reversible uptake and release of iron for use by the cell.
label: paragraph

line: Researcher: Joaquin Ray Gallegos
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Title: An Assessment of Oral Health on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation
label: paragraph

line: Research Focus: Oral Health
label: paragraph

line: School: University of Colorado Denver | Anschutz Medical Campus
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Type: Poster and Oral Presentations
label: paragraph

line: Abstract:
label: heading

line: An Assessment of Oral Health on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation
label: paragraph

line: Joaquin R Gallegos, Terry Batliner, DDS, MBA, John T Brinton, MS, Dallas M Daniels, RDH,
label: paragraph

line: BS, Anne Wilson, DDS, MS, Maxine Janis, MPH, RDH, Kimberly E Lind, MPH, Deborah H
label: paragraph

line: Glueck, PhD, Judith Albino, PhD.
label: paragraph

line: Centers for American Indian and Alaska Native Health, University of Colorado, Colorado
label: paragraph

line: School of Public Health
label: paragraph

line: W e assessed the oral health of the Pine Ridge Oglala Lakota people, described a new oral health
label: paragraph

line: assessment tool for Indigenous people, and suggested ways to improve Native oral health. The
label: paragraph

line: Check Up Study team of dentist and dental hygienists performed examinations of teeth and oral
label: paragraph

line: soft tissue for a convenience sample of 292 adults and children. Screening personnel counted the
label: paragraph

line: number of decayed, filled, sealed and total teeth, used probes to measure periodontal disease, and
label: paragraph

line: screened for oral lesions. Half of adults had 27 or fewer teeth. Sixteen percent of adults had at
label: paragraph

line: least one tooth with a pocket depth > 6mm. Participants had higher numbers of decayed teeth
label: paragraph

line: (p<0.0001), and lower numbers of filled teeth (p<0.0001) than those reflected in Indian Health
label: paragraph

line: Service cross-tribe aggregated data from 1999. Amongst Lakota people of Pine Ridge, our study
label: paragraph

line: documented a high prevalence of caries and periodontal disease, numerous people with missing
label: paragraph

line: teeth, and many unmet dental needs. Future studies of oral health related behaviors, and access to
label: paragraph

line: oral health care are needed to explain the dental, periodontal, and soft tissue problems that
label: paragraph

line: adversely affect the Oglala Lakota.
label: paragraph

line: HIGH SCHOOL
label: heading

line: Researcher: Wyatt Dunham
label: paragraph

line: P resentation Title: The Citrus Solution: Phase II
label: paragraph

line: Research Focus: Utilizing citrus pectin and citrus peels as filtrates for heavy metal pollutants
label: paragraph

line: found in a Superfund Site and the effects on Daphnia magna before and after filtration.
label: paragraph

line: School: Grove High School
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Type: Poster Presentation
label: paragraph

line: Abstract:
label: heading

line: The purpose of this experiment was to test the effectiveness of composite filters made from
label: paragraph

line: citrus peels and citrus pectin along with charcoal and sand on removing heavy metal pollutants
label: paragraph

line: from the waters of Tar Creek. A toxicity test was also done before and after filtration using
label: paragraph

line: Daphnia magna. Charcoal and sand were used as filtrates to decrease the TDS and neutralize the
label: paragraph

line: pH of the water after filtration.
label: paragraph

line: filtration.
label: paragraph

line: Daphnia magna were used as toxicity test before and after
label: paragraph

line: It was hypothesized that the composite filters (citrus + sand +charcoal) will decrease the heavy
label: paragraph

line: metal concentration, neutralize the pH, and decrease the TDS after filtration. It was also
label: paragraph

line: hypothesized that a higher percentage of Daphnia magna will survive in the filtered water as
label: paragraph

line: compared to the unfiltered water.
label: paragraph

line: Water samples were collected from four different sites at Tar Creek. Each water sample went
label: paragraph

line: through four different citrus filters plus one control (sand + charcoal). All the citrus filters
label: paragraph

line: decreased the heavy metal concentration after filtration. All of the filters neutralized the pH. The
label: paragraph

line: citrus peel filters for Site 4 were the only filters to have a pH of 7 after filtration. Only 25% of
label: paragraph

line: the citrus filters decreased the TDS after filtration, while 50% of the control filters decreased the
label: paragraph

line: TDS after filtration. A higher percentage of Daphnia magna survived after filtration. The orange
label: paragraph

line: peel had the overall highest survival of Daphnia after filtration. The correlation observed before
label: paragraph

line: and after filtration was cadmium was most toxic to Daphnia magna.
label: paragraph

line: Researcher: Oletha Hope Gould
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Title: Insect Repellant Potential of Juniper Berry (Di'zad' - Navajo name) Essential
label: paragraph

line: Oil
label: paragraph

line: Research Focus: Medicine and Health Science
label: paragraph

line: School: Newcomb High School
label: paragraph

line: Presentation Type: Poster Presentation
label: paragraph

line: Abstract:
label: heading

line: The Southwest shrub Juniperus communis (Juniper Berry) has many significant medicinal value
label: paragraph

line: in the Native American culture that has not been proven scientifically. One of the popular uses
label: paragraph

line: of Juniper berries aside from its detoxifying action is its potential to repel insects. This study
label: paragraph

line: focuses on the development of insect repellant from its essential oil obtained through steam
label: paragraph

line: distillation. 50 g of fresh berries was collected and dried for 5 days and is placed in a still
label: paragraph

line: tank with 100 mL of water for steam distillation using the Flinn Scientific Borosilicate Lab
label: paragraph

line: Kit. Gather the extracted oil and dilute 70% in three separate containers to be transferred into
label: paragraph

line: spray bottles. Testing involved the spraying of the dilute sample into a class jar with Anopheles
label: paragraph

line: juidthae (common NM mosquito) and compared this to the effect of a commercial insect
label: paragraph

line: repellant. After testing and comparing the result, the commercial insect repellant significantly
label: paragraph

line: showed that it is a better insect repellant compared to the J. communis diluted essential
label: paragraph

line: oil. However, the essential oil has also an insect repellant potential.
label: paragraph
